trial_identification.studytitle: Therapy for acute posttrauma stress after recent sexual assault
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Treatment of acute stress disorder secondary to sexual assault in adults: Effectiveness of cognitive processing therapy compared with treatment as usual in a community mental health setting

interventions.interventions: Cognitive processing therapy (CPT): participants receive 6 weekly sessions of a trauma-focussed cognitive behavioural psychological therapy, with each session being 90min duration. Therapy is conducted one on one with counsellor (social worker). Cognitive behavioural therapy techniques involves helping participants modify unhelpful beliefs that contribute to anxiety and stress, and methods to reduce the frequency and distress associated with trauma memories.
interventions.comparator: Treatment as usual (TAU): participants receive standard counselling as normally received in a rape and sexual assault service.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome 1: Mean posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) severity score derived from the Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: pretreatment, posttreatment, 3-months after treatment, 6-months after treatment.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome 2: Mean PTSD severity score on PTSD Checklist.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: pretreatment, posttreatment, 3-months after treatment, 6-months after treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary outcome: Mean Beck depression score.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: pretreatment, posttreatment, 3-months after treatment, 6-months after treatment.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Has experienced a sexual assault within past 4 weeks and is diagnosed with Acute Stress Disorder.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Client actively suicidal, has uncontrolled psychosis or bipolar disorder, is in current threat (e.g., is being actively stalked by a perpetrator), meets criteria for substance dependence, is already receiving psychotherapy for the index assault.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study has several aims: (1) to test whether cognitive processing therapy (CPT) is helpful after recent trauma; (2) to test that CPT is as good as the usual therapy delivered in the sexual assault service (treatment as usual, TAU); (3) to ensure that counsellors not previously trained in CPT can learn and deliver the therapy with the same results as previous studies that have used highly experienced and trained cognitive behavioural therapists. We predict that CPT will be useful in reducing posttraumatic stress, that it will be at a minimum as good as treatment as usual, and we hypothesise that CPT therapists will show results comparable to previous treatment outcome studies using CPT.
